Authors:
Xiao E Xiao, Wen Wang, H. K. Wang, Jianping Xu, Pedro W.
Crous, H. Y. Li
Title:
Species of Botryosphaeriaceae associated with citrus branch
diseases in China
Keywords:
Botryosphaeria cankers, distribution, new taxa,
pathogenicity, systematics
Abstract:
Citrus is an important and widely cultivated fruit crop in
South China. Although the diseases of leaves and fruits have been
extensively studied, the causal organisms of branch diseases remain
poorly known in China. Species of Botryosphaeriaceae are known as
important fungal pathogens causing branch diseases on citrus in the USA
and Europe. To determine the diversity of Botryosphaeriaceae species
associated with citrus branch diseases in China, surveys were conducted
in the major citrus-producing areas from 2017 to 2020. Diseased tissues
were collected from twigs, branches and trunks with a range of symptoms
including cankers, cracking, dieback and gummosis. Based on
morphological characteristics and phylogenetic comparison of the DNA
sequences of the internal transcribed spacer region (ITS), the
translation elongation factor 1-alpha gene (tef1), the Î²-tubulin gene
(tub) and the DNA-directed RNA polymerase II subunit (rpb2), 111
isolates from nine provinces were identified as 21 species of
Botryosphaeriaceae, including Botryosphaeria dothidea, B. fabicerciana,
Diplodia seriata, Dothiorella alpina, Do. plurivora, Lasiodiplodia
citricola, L. iraniensis, L. pseudotheobromae, L. theobromae,
Neodeightonia subglobosa, Neofusicoccum parvum, and 10 previously
undescribed species, namely Dothiorella citrimurcott, Do. yongquanensis,
L. citrigrandis, L. guilinsis, L. huangyanensis, L. linhaisis, L.
lishuisis, L. ponkan, L. valencia and Sphaeropsis linhaina spp. nov.
Botryosphaeria dothidea (28.8 %) was the most abundant species, followed
by L. pseudotheobromae (23.4 %), which was the most widely distributed
species on citrus, occurring in six of the nine provinces sampled.
Pathogenicity tests, both in vitro and in vivo, indicated that all 21
species of Botryosphaeriaceae obtained from diseased citrus tissues in
this study were pathogenic to the tested citrus shoots and that
Lasiodiplodia was the most aggressive genus. This is the first study to
identify Botryosphaeriaceae species related to citrus branch diseases in
China and the results provide a theoretical basis for the implementation
of prevention and control measures.
